results.title: Community life, women and the Temple of Karnak
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Ancient lives”.
John Romer focuses on the role of women in ancient Egypt and their rituals such as birthing practices as well as reading some Egyptian love poetry. Romer explains the mathematical perfection of the Great Temple of Karnak, and provides an insight into the workings of the village oracle, the supernatural and medical treatment.

results.title: Ancient gold mines and temples
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Ancient lives”.
John Romer details the life of Paneb, one of the most extraordinary men who lived in the village of Deir El medina; village of the Royal Tomb makers. He also examines the famed erotic papyrus of Turin, visits the ancient gold mines where criminals were sentenced to a life of hard labour in the most inhumane conditions and tours the great temple of Medinet Habu.

results.title: The Royal tombs
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Ancient lives”.
The villagers of Deir El Medina, just outside Thebes, was the home of the Royal Tomb builders and painters of ancient Egypt. John Romer, British archaeologist explains how the villagers’ lives fitted into the highly organised Egyptian society. He explores the tombs in the Valley of the Kings and explains how the beautiful wall paintings and carved reliefs were executed and their changed design over time. The program visits Tutankhamun’s tomb, the temple of Deir El Medina, the village tomb of Ipy and the tombs of Kha in Turin.

results.title: Andy Hardy Series
results.brief_description: One of the most popular US series, the Hardy family first appeared in “A Family Affair” 1937 with Lionel Barrymore and Mickey Rooney as father and son. In 1938 “You’re Only Young Once” began the official series in the town of Carvel, with Rooney as Andy Hardy, typical American teenager, interested in girls and fast cars, Lewis Stone as James Judge Hardy, a stern but understanding father, Fay Holden as his “swell” mother, Cecilia Parker as Marian, his older sister striving to be a young lady, Sara Haden as Aunt Millie and Ann Rutherford as Polly, the girlfriend who was often neglected for other prospects but to whom Andy always returned. George B. Seitz directed most of the series. A testament to the series’ great appeal was the special Oscar given MGM “for its achievement in representing the American Way of Life.” MGM used the films to springboard young starlets such as Judy Garland, Lana Turner, Esther Williams, Kathryn Grayson and Donna Reed. The Hardy films serve as a reminder of an era in Hollywood and America that is long gone.

results.title: Andy Hardy's private secretary
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Andy Hardy Series”.
Mickey Rooney is lovable as the evervescent teenager Andy with the stern judge father and understanding mother. Andy is about to graduate from high school and gets an inflated opinion of himself. He hires a social secretary played by Kathryn Grayson to sort out his complicated domestic affairs. Grayson does a superb rendition of Strauss’ “Voices of Spring.”

results.title: Andy Hardy meets debutante
results.creator_credit: George B. Seitz, Loews Incorporated and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Andy Hardy Series”.
Andy (Mickey Rooney) is dazzled by a picture in a magazine of a glamorous debutante (Diana Lewis). When Judge Hardy’s (Lewis Stone) crusade to save an orphanage takes him to New York City, Andy joins him in the hope of meeting his dream girl. However, the Big Apple shows little sympathy for a cocky, small town boy and his hairbrained schemes to break into high society backfire with disastrous but humerous results. Finally, his old pal Betsy Booth (Judy Garland), a high society girl herself, lends Andy a hand - and a tuxedo. This is one of the most entertaining films in the series and features Judy Garland performing “Alone” and “I’m Nobody’s Baby.”

results.title: Love finds Andy Hardy
results.creator_credit: George B. Seitz, Loews Incorporated and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Andy Hardy Series”.
The fourth film in the series and the first to put Andy’s name in the title. The story moves at a jitterbug pace along comic and heartfelt storylines. Andy (Mickey Rooney) is in a fix as he has made dates for the Christmas dance with steady girlfriend Polly (Anne Rutherford) and voluptuous Cynthia (Lana Turner). Meanwhile Dad (Lewis Stone) must oversee the household while Mum (Fay Holden) is caring for Grandma. The new kid next door (Judy Garland in the first of three fondly remembered Andy Hardy appearances) helps Andy out of his jam and how she does it is an absolute delight, as are her renditions of “It never rains but what it pours”, “In-Between” and “Meet the beat of my heart.”

results.title: Goosebumps
results.creator_credit: Steve Levitan, Protocol Entertainment and Scholastic Productions
results.brief_description: R.L. Stine’s popular horror stories for children became a television series. Each episode contains a complete scary story, most with an unusual twist.

results.title: The Great commanders
results.creator_credit: Phil Grabsky and Seventh Art Productions
results.brief_description: A six part series which looks at six individuals considered to be military giants. Their motivation and the qualities which made them great commanders are analysed by experts. 3D computer animation is used to illustrate each commander’s particular skill in battle. Each program takes as its focus a key battle which examines the nature of each individual’s military command.

results.title: Napoleon Bonaparte and the Battle of Austerlitz
results.creator_credit: Phil Grabsky and Seventh Art Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Great commanders”.
Napoleon remains one of the most enigmatic and skillful military leaders the world has ever seen. Exploiting the turmoil of the French Revolution, Napoleon was able to eventually become Emperor of France and then set his sights towards the rest of Europe. At the Battle of Austerlitz, Napoleon was able to command a victory against Austria and Russia.
